# Try via CLI

You can compile a file directly via `bsc MyFile.res`:

<CodeTab>

```res
// MyFile.res
let rec fib = n => {
  switch n {
  | 0 | 1 => 1
  | n => fib (n -1) + fib(n-2)
  }
}
Js.log(fib(0))
```

```re
let rec fib = n =>
  switch (n) {
  | 0
  | 1 => 1
  | n => fib(n - 1) + fib(n - 2)
  };

Js.log(fib(0));
```

</CodeTab>

```sh
❯ bsc MyFile.res
// Generated by BUCKLESCRIPT, PLEASE EDIT WITH CARE
'use strict';
function fib(n) {
  if (n === 0 || n === 1) {
    return 1;
  } else {
    return fib(n - 1 | 0) + fib(n - 2 | 0) | 0;
  }
}
console.log(fib(0));
exports.fib = fib;
/*  Not a pure module */
```

You can also get the inferred signature directly via `bsc -i MyFile.res`

```resi
let fib: int => int
```

<!-- You can quickly test code snippets in the console: -->
<!-- ``` -->
<!-- ❯ bsc -e 'let add = (x, y) => x + y' -->
<!-- // Generated by BUCKLESCRIPT, PLEASE EDIT WITH CARE -->
<!-- 'use strict'; -->
<!--  -->
<!--  -->
<!-- function id(x) { -->
<!-- return x; -->
<!-- } -->
<!--  -->
<!-- exports.id = id; -->
<!-- ``` -->
<!--  -->
<!-- Pass the `-i` flag to infer the signature: -->
<!--  -->
<!-- ``` -->
<!-- ❯ bsc -i -e 'let id = x => x' -->
<!-- let id: 'a => 'a; -->
<!-- ``` -->
